results.title: Drivers I have known and hated
results.brief_description: Looks at some of the most aggravating and dangerous drivers on the roads today and identifies many frustrating and hazardous situations caused by drivers with poor attitudes. Inspires viewers to examine their own driving habits.

results.title: Driven to kill
results.brief_description: A driving safety film profiling the character Hal Johnston, a safety conscious family man, an average American, a careful and considerate person - but a complete monster behind the wheel. Hal eventually befalls a bitter end and the narrative steers into sequences of more sorroful driving, a pretty girl with a big facial scar and a young couple with missing limbs. This film received an award from the National Committee on Films for Safety and was estimated that over 15 million people saw this film in the first year of its release. Prosaically narrated by Lowell Thomas.

results.title: Drive smart: improve your driving skills before you take the test (PC)
results.brief_description: Drive smart is an interactive package designed to assist learner drivers in improving driver education, safety and skills, before taking the all important driver’s licence test. Each module will help you become familiar with the necessary responses and actions required when driving, including scanning and hazard perception and making judgements on a number of driving scenarios and quizzes. It is emphasised that this is a training supplement and is not designed to replace supervised driving practice. “Drive smart” was developed with the assistance of Monash University Accident Research Centre over a period of three years using state of the art driving simulators. For more information visit www.drivesmart.vic.gov.au.

results.title: Drive By Shooting
results.brief_description:
In this sombre study of urban violent crime, American filmmaker Andy Anderson has filmed the spaces in which literally hundreds of crimes occured within the district of Fort Worth, Texas. Filmed from a passing car, suburban homes, carparks, empty lots glide by on the screen every 15 seconds, the time in which a new gun related murder occurs every day in the USA. Over these images the filmmaker reads details from the police blotter of the committed crime. The result is an overwhelming and deeply impactful exploration of a society being decimated by gun related crime. A powerful statement for gun control as well as a profound memorial for the victims of crime.

“I have always been fascinated by turning over rocks to see what is just out of sight.

How many times have you read of a crime happening in your neighborhood, then some time later, driving by the scene thought “Oh… that’s where that happened.”

Like Dealy Plaza in Dallas (JFK assinsation site), you can no longer pass that location and not think of the crime, it has lost its identity. The crime takes it and makes it forever a “crime scene.”

Just below the manicured surface of our suburban neighborhoods is a layer of faceless, nameless, ordinary crime… the kind that doesn’t make the evening TV News, or rate space in the morning paper… the kind that is relentless, pervasive and most importantly, personal… the kind that makes us less than a society. Less than human beings…

From police blotters and crime reports come stories of these violations. Flatly narrated in the “cop speak” of the reports, these stories are matched to the locations by block number and filmed in a drive-by shooting. Hundreds of these scenes/stories are presented, one after another, every fifteen seconds for two hours (the rate at which they occur) then repeated continuously…

You may turn away, or walk away, but the tape will still be playing when you get back… four crimes a minute… ” - Andy Anderson

results.title: Drip
results.creator_credit: Stuart Finley and Stuart Finley Productions
results.brief_description: Many thousands of gallons of water are unnecessarily wasted every day in America - and all over the world, especially in affluent countries. This film stresses the need for a community “Save Water” campaign.
results.description: Many thousands of gallons of water are unnecessarily wasted every day in America - and all over the world, especially in affluent countries. This film stresses the need for a community “Save Water” campaign.

results.title: Drinking: how will Charlie handle it?
results.brief_description: The film presents a variety of social and emotional factors which can influence an individual’s decision about drinking. Considers abstinence, drinking in moderation, and a number of consequences of excessive drinking. The film offers no conclusions but is designed to promote thought and discussion about the decision-making process regarding drinking.

results.title: Drinking driving: Danger level
results.brief_description: Examines the effect of alcohol on driving performance. Scientific tests were carried out at Warwick Farm motor racing circuit, using drivers given carefully measured quantities of alcohol. From the results of these experiments, a danger level of alcohol consumption was able to be ascertained.

results.title: Drinking-driving. Edited version
results.creator_credit: Warren J Mills, Ansvar Insurance and Christopher Productions
results.brief_description: An experiment conducted by the University of New South Wales shows that the intake of alcohol has a detrimental effect on the driving performance of both the ordinary motorist and the skilled racing driver. Shows both drivers tackling a course before drinking, and then at blood-alcohol levels of .05 and .08.

results.title: Drinking
results.creator_credit: Joe Licastro, Floyd Elliott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: By alternating live-action sequences and animated graphics, the film follows the behavioral and physiological transformations that are directly linked to consumption of alcohol. It shows the short-term and long-term effects on the human body.

results.title: Drink no Longer Water
results.creator_credit: Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and Fontana Films
results.brief_description: A humourous romp through various wine styles set in the country in a castle-like structure. Vignettes played out by actors - some in period costume to emulate the character of various wine varieties/styles from Moselle “for first lovers” through to claret are you old enough? Featuring Australian actors Steve Bisley and Mel Gibson in their youth.
